title-group.article-title: Letter to the editor: a commentary on “Integrating machine learning and molecular docking to decipher the molecular network of aflatoxin b1-induced hepatocellular carcinoma”

body.p: We read with great interest the study by Gao et al titled “Integrating machine learning and molecular docking to decipher the molecular network of aflatoxin b1-induced hepatocellular carcinoma”[1]. The research team employed a multidisciplinary approach, combining machine learning, network toxicology, and molecular docking techniques, to investigate the pathogenesis of aflatoxin B1 (AFB1) in hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). This study provides important theoretical insights into the specific mechanisms by which AFB1 induces HCC.

By integrating multiple datasets and applying various bioinformatics techniques, the authors successfully identified six core genes (RND3, PCK1, AURKA, BCAT2, UCK2, and CCNB1) that are closely associated with the development and progression of HCC. Additionally, the study used molecular docking to validate the interactions between these genes and AFB1, further strengthening the reliability of the findings. These discoveries not only provide valuable clues for AFB1-related molecular targets but also lay the foundation for future targeted therapies and prevention strategies for HCC.

However, there are still some aspects that warrant further exploration. First, although the study utilized several publicly available transcriptomic datasets, the sample size is relatively small, and the diversity of samples from different regions is limited, which may affect the generalizability of the results. Therefore, future research should increase the sample size, particularly by expanding clinical samples from high-risk regions, to enhance the representativeness and reliability of the study. Second, while the authors have drawn valuable conclusions through computational simulations and machine learning, the lack of experimental validation (e.g., in vitro and in vivo experiments) means that the biological significance of the conclusions has not been fully confirmed. Future studies should include more experimental validation to verify the roles of these genes. Lastly, although the study accounted for some confounding factors (such as age, genetic background, and lifestyle), other unmeasured variables (such as environmental factors and exposure to pollutants) may still influence the accuracy of the results.

We believe that future research can be directed toward several key areas. First, it is essential to experimentally validate these six core genes through techniques such as gene knockdown and overexpression to further confirm their biological roles in AFB1-induced HCC. Second, conducting long-term cohort studies, particularly targeting high-risk populations, will help reveal the dose-response relationship between AFB1 exposure and HCC development. Additionally, targeted intervention studies focusing on the six core genes identified in this research could explore the potential for modulating their expression to prevent or treat AFB1-induced HCC, providing a new direction for precision therapy.

In conclusion, the study by Gao et al offers an in-depth analysis of the mechanisms underlying AFB1-induced HCC and lays the groundwork for future research and clinical applications. But further experimental validation and more extensive clinical research are needed to confirm these findings and explore their clinical translational potential.

sec.title: Declaration and use of AI
sec.p: No artificial intelligence tools were used in the design, execution, or writing of this study, and our article is compliant with the TITAN Guidelines 2025.[2]
